subject: Re: [junit] Separate Assertion Object
msgSnippet: Quoth Curt Sampson: [...] ... Since these routines are static methods of Assert, I always had the impression that TestCase subclasses Assert so you can write
messageBody:
Quoth Curt Sampson:
[...]
> Why does a TestCase inherit all of its assertion routines?

Since these routines are static methods of Assert, I always had
the impression that TestCase subclasses Assert so you can write
assert(...)
instead of the slightly more verbose
Assert.assert(...) .
That is, inheritance is used to bring the methods into a more
convenient namespace. (This is a Java-specific trick; it doesn't
work so well in PyUnit, for example.)

[...]
> That led me to start thinking about whether it might not be cleaner and
> simpler, overall, to completely separate the assertion code from the test
> cases by using separate assertion objects for everything.

Makes sense to me.

We don't even have to lose the namespace convenience: TestCase
could implement the assertion interface and delegate to a separate
object specified at, say, construction time.
